Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Entrainment and Task Success in Team Conversations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Teams, rather than individuals, are now the usual generators of scientific knowledge. How to optimize team interactions is a passionately pursued topic across several disciplines. This research hypothesizes that linguistic entrainment, or the convergence of linguistic properties of spoken conversation, may serve as a valid and relatively easy-to-collect measure that is predictive of team success. From the perspective of developing interventions for team innovation, organizations could unobtrusively measure team effectiveness using entrainment, and intervene with training to aid teams with low entrainment. Similar interventions would be useful for conversational agents that monitor and facilitate group interactions. The work could also support the development of browsers or data mining applications for corpora such as team meetings or classroom discussions.

To date, most studies of entrainment have focused on conversational dyads rather than the multi-party conversations typical of teams. The technical objective of this research is to develop, validate and evaluate new measures of linguistic entrainment tailored to multi-party conversations. In particular, the first research goal is to develop multi-party entrainment measures that are computable using language technologies, and that are both motivated and validated by the literature on teams. The second goal is to demonstrate the utility of these measures in being associated with team processes and predicting team success. The supporting activities include 1) collection of an experimentally-obtained corpus where teams collaborate on a task where they converse, and where a team process intervention manipulates likely entrainment, 2) development of a set of entrainment measures for multi-party dialogue, 3) use of standard psychological teamwork measures for convergent validity and random conversations for divergent validity, 4) exploration of how the team factors of gender composition and participation equality impact group entrainment, and 5) evaluation of the utility of measuring entrainment for predicting team and dialogue success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teams, rather than individuals, are now the usual generators of scientific knowledge. This research tests how linguistic entrainment, or the convergence of properties of spoken conversation (e.g., words, sounds), may be related to team task and social success. This project’s goals were: (1) create a sharable dataset of team interactions, including transcripts and audio and video data; (2) develop new team (rather than dyadic) measures of linguistic entrainment; (3) compare standard psychological teamwork measures such as cohesion to the new measures of entrainment; (4) explore how team factors such as demographic composition (e.g., personality diversity, gender diversity) influence entrainment; and (5) evaluate the usefulness of entrainment in predicting team task and social success.

 

We collected data with 63 teams of three or four individuals for 216 total participants. These teams played a cooperative, multi-role board game, Forbidden Island ™, twice. The participants were 33% non-students and 63% female. Participants could choose more than one race/ethnicity: most chose Caucasian (166), then Asian (31), Black/African-American (24), and Hispanic (10). Audio and video data were collected, as well as personality surveys and post-game perceptions of group processes and conflict. As of September 2017, the transcripts from the first games are almost complete and ready for sharing, providing a useful resource for communities that study team interactions such as computer science, computational linguistics, communications, and psychology. We have developed a variety of simple measures of acoustic (sound-based) and lexical (word-based) team entrainment. We found that team entrainment occurs in our corpus for a variety of acoustic and lexical measures, and that different types of team entrainment correlate with different types of outcomes. We will continue to develop new, more complex algorithms for measures that take into account complex team dynamics. These new measures will be an additional resource for other researchers interested in studying entrainment.

 

We have conducted statistical analyses on what factors may influence team social and task success. Different acoustic entrainment measures were tested for whether they were associated with social success in the same game (all game 1) or could predict social success in the next game played (game 2). We found that measures of convergence on mean intensity (loudness) for the first game were negatively associated with self-reported favorable social outcomes, controlling for significant covariates. In other words, convergence on loudness was, counter-intuitively, associated with more conflict and lower self-reported favorable social processes for the same game. We also found that some of the convergence measures for the first game, as expected, were positively related to the second game’s favorable social outcomes, controlling for the first game’s social outcomes. Convergence on maximum pitch was negatively related to task conflict, and convergence on maximum intensity was positively related to favorable group perceptions. Thus, convergence on certain acoustic measures on the first game was associated with a more positive team experience on the second game. In addition, we found that educational attainment diversity (i.e., more breadth from high school to PhD graduates in the team) was positively related to a measure of task performance on the board game on the second round, controlling for performance on the first round of the game, team size, average age, and gender composition. Data analysis and writing will continue: We have many more measures of entrainment and social and task success to examine.

 

This study had both intellectual and broader benefits. In addition to being a novel, multidisciplinary study of team entrainment, this study provides a wealth of data that will provide a testbed for the creation of entrainment measures for years to come. Once we determine what types of entrainment are associated with what types of social and task success, we can test the relationships in other datasets to see if they replicate with real-world teams. The dataset created by this project will provide a useful resource for researchers in multiple disciplines. In addition, as we and others develop more refined measures of entrainment, organizations can use these measures to unobtrusively examine team processes, and they can intervene with training to aid teams with low entrainment.
